author: barnabemonnot
content: sorry if it was unclear. by individual attestations i mean unique votes by individual validators (sometimes a vote is included several times, across several aggregates, in this case it is only counted once). i compare that number to the number of aggregates included in blocks. it tells me how much we save by using the aggregation mechanism versus including each vote individually, since aggregating 100 votes into one aggregate is 1/100th of the space needed to save the same 100 votes individually

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> What I didn't understand are the numbers. If you have 23.82 individual attestations and one aggregate with 100 attestations, then you'll need approx 5 times the size to store the same data without the aggregate.
<@755590043632140352>  sure, if you have let’s say 23.82 (let’s say 24 to round it) aggregates of size 1 included on chain and one aggregate of size 100, assuming all 124 votes contained in these 25 aggregates are unique, then the savings ratio would be 124 / 25 ~ 5. In the data I present there are ~350M unique votes contained in ~14M aggregates on chain, hence the 23x ratio.

author: barnabemonnot
content: By the way, not saying that’s the only metric worth looking at (in fact i present a few more), but it’s perhaps a good indicator of how valuable the aggregation process is. It’s quite fundamental to allow for the large number of validators that eth2 expects
